Published 5 February 2021 Article Direct growth of holey Fe3O4-coupled Ni(OH)2 sheets on nickel foam for the oxygen evolution reaction Yu Ding a † Bo-Qiang Miao b † Yue Zhao b Fu-Min Li a Yu-Cheng Jiang a # Shu-Ni Li a * Yu Chen b a Key Laboratory of Macromolecular Science of Shaanxi Province, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710062, Shaanxi, China Key Laboratory of Macromolecular Science of Shaanxi Province School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shaanxi Normal University Xi'an Shaanxi 710062 China Key Laboratory of Macromolecular Science of Shaanxi Province, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710062, Shaanxi, China b School of Materials Science and Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710062, Shaanxi, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Shaanxi Normal University Xi'an Shaanxi 710062 China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710062, Shaanxi, China * Corresponding author # Corresponding author † These authors contributed to this work equally. The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a half-reaction of water electrolysis, and the OER performance of an electrocatalyst is significantly related to its energy conversion efficiency. Due to their high OER activity, transition metal-based nanomaterials have become potential low-cost substitutes for Ir/Ru-based OER electrocatalysts in an alkaline environment. Herein, holey Fe3O4-coupled Ni(OH)2 sheets (Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs) were easily achieved by a simple mixed-cyanogel hydrolysis strategy. The two-dimensional (2D) Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs with ca. 1 nm thickness have a high specific surface area, abundant unsaturated coordination atoms, and numerous pores, which are highly favorable for electrocatalytic reactions. Meanwhile, the introduction of Fe improves the conductivity and regulates the electronic structure of Ni. Due to their special structural features and synergistic effect between the Fe and Ni atoms, Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs with an optimal Ni/Fe ratio show excellent OER activity in a 1 M KOH solution, which significantly exceeds that of the commercial RuO2 nanoparticle electrocatalyst. Furthermore, Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs can be grown on nickel foam (NF), and the resulting material exhibits enhanced OER activity, such as a small overpotential of 200 mV and a small Tafel slope of 56 mV dec−1, than that of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs without NF. Graphical Abstract Herein, ultrathin holey Fe3O4-coupled Ni(OH)2 sheets (Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs) were easily synthesized, which showed outstanding activity for the OER due to special structural features and synergistic effect between the Fe and Ni atom. Keywords Oxygen evolution reaction Transition metal-based nanomaterials Holey two-dimensional materials Heteroatom doping Electrocatalysis 1 Introduction Recently, oxygen evolution reaction (OER)-based electrochemical energy conversion systems (such as electrochemical hydrogen production, nitrogen electroreduction, and carbon dioxide electroreduction systems and metal-air batteries) are attracting increasing attention [ 1–6 ]. Thus, the achievement of anode catalysts with a high OER performance will undoubtedly elevate the energy conversion efficiency of these systems. Although Ru-, Rh-, and Ir-based nanomaterials are highly active and durable OER catalysts [ 7–11 ], their low earth-abundance and prohibitively high cost may limit their industrial application. Recently, various transition metal (Mn, Ni, Co, Fe, and Cu)-based nanomaterials (sulfides, hydroxides, oxides, phosphides, and nitrides) have been regarded as highly promising precious metal-alternative OER catalysts in an alkaline environment [ 12–26 ]. Among them, Ni(OH)2-based OER electrocatalysts have attracted wide attention because of their high activity and low cost [ 27–40 ]. The electroactivity of Ni(OH)2-based nanomaterials is significantly related to their morphology and chemical composition due to the area, structural, electronic, and synergistic effects. For instance, Wang et al. [ 33 ] synthesized ultrathin Ni(OH)2 sheets with 1.4 nm thickness, which revealed a higher OER mass activity than thicker Ni(OH)2 sheets because of their considerable surface area and abundant exposed active atoms on their surface [ 33 ]. Bott-Neto et al. [ 41 ] synthesized ultra-small spherical Ni(OH)2 nanoparticles with a size of only 2.4 nm, which revealed excellent electroactivity for the oxidation of methanol, ethanol, and glycerol due to the area effect. Du et al. [ 40 ] synthesized CeO2 nanoparticle-decorated Ni(OH)2 sheets, which had a higher OER activity than the Ni(OH)2 sheets. The synergistic effect between the CeO2 nanoparticles and the Ni(OH)2 sheets increased the charge transfer rate and the amount of NiIII/IV active species in the Ni(OH)2 sheets, which were responsible for the high OER activity [ 40 ]. Huang et al. [ 42 ] directly grew Ni(OH)2 sheets on porous nickel, which displayed a high sensitivity and fast response for glucose sensing. The porous nickel substrate provided a large surface area for the loading of Ni(OH)2 sheets and accelerated molecular transport. Consequently, this structural effect contributed to the high activity of this material for glucose oxidation [ 42 ]. Peng et al. [ 43 ] achieved holey Ni(OH)2 sheets by a sol-gel method, which exhibited a higher activity than pristine Ni(OH)2 sheets for the OER. The introduction of nanopores not only accelerated mass transport, but also increased the amount of edge-active atoms, which were obviously advantageous for activity enhancement [ 43 ]. According to the abovementioned examples, 2D ultrathin sheets have unique structural characteristics, which can provide a high surface area and substantial surface atoms with a low-coordination number for electrocatalytic reactions. The introduction of heteroatoms may tune the electronic and geometrical structures of nanomaterials, which generally enhances their electroactivity. Moreover, three-dimensional (3D) nickel foam (NF) can prevent the aggregation of the loaded nanomaterials and improve the mass transfer of reactants/products. Inspired by the expected results, herein, we directly synthesized holey Fe3O4-coupled Ni(OH)2 sheets (denoted as Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs) on the NF substrate (denoted as Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs/NF). Because of large surface area, enough active atoms, synergistic effect between the Fe and Ni atoms, high conductivity, and 3D porous feature of NF, Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs/NF shows an excellent OER performance, including a small overpotential of 200 mV at 10 mA cm−2 current density, a small Tafel slope of 56 mV dec−1, and outstanding stability, in KOH solution. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and reagents Nickel(II) chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O, ≥98.0%), iron(III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O, ≥98.0%), and sodium borohydride (NaBH4, 98%) were provided by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Potassium cyanonickelate(II) ((K2Ni(CN)4)·xH2O, 98%) was obtained from Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Potassium hydroxide (KOH, ≥95%) was purchased from Alfa Aesar. 2.2 Synthesis of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs with different Ni/Fe ratios can be easily achieved by a simple mixed-cyanogel hydrolysis strategy. Herein, we chose Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs with a Ni/Fe ratio of 3:1 (denoted as Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1) as a typical example. Typically, the NiCl2-K2Ni(CN)4/FeCl3-K2Ni(CN)4 mixed cyanogel was obtained within 15 min by adding 0.374 mmol FeCl3, 0.624 mmol NiCl2, and 0.5 mmol K2Ni(CN)4 to 4 mL water (Fig. S1). Then, Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 was obtained by adding 50 mL of 3.5 M NaBH4 solution to the NiCl2-K2Ni(CN)4/ FeCl3-K2Ni(CN)4 mixed cyanogel and heating the mixture for 7 h at 70 °C in a water bath. The products were centrifuged and obtained after the reaction followed by drying at 40 °C overnight. For comparison, other Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs with different Ni/Fe atomic ratios were prepared by adjusting the amount of nickel chloride and iron chloride, which were donated as Ni(OH)2 H-STs, Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni5Fe1, Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni1Fe1, and Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni0.5Fe1. 2.3 Synthesis of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 on NF (Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1/NF) The same cyanogel hydrolysis strategy can be applied to directly grow Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 on NF. Neat NF was immersed in 4 mL NiCl2-K2Ni(CN)4/FeCl3-K2Ni(CN)4 mixed cyanogel. After heating this mixture in a water bath at 70 °C for 7 h as abovementioned in Section 2.1, Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1/NF was obtained. 2.4 Physical characterization Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), selected area electron diffraction (SAED), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were conducted at a voltage of 200 kV using TECNAI G2 F20. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was conducted at 15 kV using SU8220. N2 isotherm adsorption/desorption (N2-IAD) was implemented using the ASAP 2020 micropore physisorption analyzer at 77 K. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was carried out using Bruker D8 Advance. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted using AXIS ULTRA of Kratos Analytical Ltd., and all binding energies were corrected by the C 1s peak at 284.6 eV. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) was conducted using Bruker Dimension ICON in tapping mode. 2.5 Electrochemical measurements A typical three-electrode system comprising a saturated calomel electrode (reference electrode), carbon rod (counter electrode), and modified glassy carbon electrode or modified NF (working electrode) was used to perform electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), cyclic voltammetry, and chronopotentiometry using the CHI-660 instrument at 30 °C. Herein, all potentials were normalized to the reversible hydrogen electrode. LSV curves were manually calibrated to compensate the iR drop of the solution. By referring to previous studies, we prepared a catalyst-modified working electrode [ 44 ]. Under strong ultrasonic vibration conditions, 10 mg electrocatalyst was dispersed in 4 mL water and 1 mL isopropanol to form a uniform solution. Then, 4 μL ink was placed on the electrode surface, and 4 μL 0.5 wt% Nafion was placed on the surface of the electrocatalyst-modified working electrode followed by drying at 50 °C. The effective loading of the electrocatalyst was ∼0.114 mg cm−2. Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs/NF with a loading of 0.8 mg cm−2 was directly used as a working electrode. The RuO2 nanoparticle (Aladdin Industrial Corporation) ink solution was prepared by strong ultrasonication to disperse 10 mg RuO2 in a mixed solution containing 4 mL water, 50 μL 5 wt% Nafion, and 1 mL isopropyl alcohol. Then, 400 μL ink solution was placed on the NF surface and dried at 50 °C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs The chemical composition of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 was investigated by EDX (Fig. 1(A) ). The EDX data reveals that Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 is composed of three elements: Ni, Fe, and O. The strong O signal suggests that the products may be oxides or hydroxides of nickel and iron. Moreover, the atomic ratio of Ni/Fe is ca 3:1, close to the feed ratio. The crystallographic texture of the products was characterized by XRD (Fig. 1(B)). The diffraction peaks of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 correspond to the characteristic diffraction peaks of Fe3O4 (JCPDS 28-0491) and Ni(OH)2 (JCPDS 22-0444). The surface components and valence states of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-Ni3Fe1 were analysed by XPS. The Fe 2p XPS spectrum shows the 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 doublet peaks and relevant weak satellite peaks (Fig. 1(C)). The Fe 2p 1/2 and Fe 2p 3/2 peaks at 723.9 and 710.1 eV are attributed to the FeII species. The Fe 2p 3/2 and Fe 2p 1/2 peaks at 725.1 and 712.1 eV correspond to the FeIII species. The Ni 2p XPS spectrum shows the presence of NiII species, which is represented by a doublet at 852.9 and 870.5 eV and two satellite peaks at 859.3 and 876.9 eV (Fig. 1(D)). Compared with the case of the Ni 2p XPS spectrum of Ni(OH)2 H-STs without Fe, the binding energy of the Ni 2p peak for Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 negatively shifts by ca. 0.3 eV (Fig. S2), indicating partial electron transfer from Fe to Ni. The SEM image shows that Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 has a flower-like morphology (Fig. 2(A) ). The magnified SEM image displays that the nanoflowers are composed of numerous sheets (Fig. 2(B)). The lamellar structure of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 was further confirmed by TEM (Fig. 2(C)). The TEM image clearly shows a lamellar structure with folds. The inset image in Fig. 2(C) shows some black thin lines that can indicate the thickness of the lamellae [ 45 ], showing an ultra-thin lamellar structure of ca. 1 nm. AFM characterization further showed that the ultra-thin thickness of the lamellar structure is ca. 1 nm (Fig. 2(D)), similar to the TEM observation. The scanning TEM-EDX (STEM-EDX) mapping images display the presence of Fe, Ni, and O, and their distributions are similar, which further suggest that the products are composed of nickel-iron oxides or hydroxides (Fig. 2(E)). Herein, 2D Ni(OH)2-Fe sheets can be easily generated from the lamellate skeletons of cyanogel precursor [ 46–50 ]. Specifically, the generated Ni and Fe atoms preferentially grow in the direction of the lamellate skeleton of cyanogel precursor, which leads to the formation of sheets. Meanwhile, the Ni2+ and Fe3+ precursors are uniformly mixed at the atomic level during the generation of NiCl2-K2Ni(CN)4/FeCl3-K2Ni(CN)4 mixed-cyanogel; this leads to the uniform distribution of Fe and Ni atoms in Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1. Structural features of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 were further explored by high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM). Nanoholes of about 1 nm are observed in the HR-TEM image (Fig. 3(A) ). The N2 IAD curves display a typical IV hysteresis loop, which confirms the porous characteristic of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs (Fig. 3(B)). The surface area of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 is measured to be 181.6 m2 g−1, and the pore width is 0.96 nm. These pores mainly originate from the natural exfoliation of cyanide ions and chloride ions during cyanogel hydrolysis [ 47–49 ]. The presence of these pores increases the mass transfer of reactants as well as the amount of edge-active atoms, which are extremely favorable for electrocatalytic reactions. Clear lattice stripes can be observed in the magnified HR-TEM image (Fig. 3(C)), which refers to the crystallographic (210) plane of Fe3O4 and (103) plane of Ni(OH)2; this is in agreement with the EDX and XRD results. The SAED pattern of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 shows obvious diffraction rings corresponding to Ni(OH)2 and Fe3O4, revealing the polycrystalline property (Fig. 3(D)). 3.2 OER performance of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs As the chemical composition of an electrocatalyst strongly affects its electrocatalytic performance, the effect of Fe content on the OER performance of Ni(OH)2 should be investigated. For this, four Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs with different Ni/Fe atomic ratios, which included Ni(OH)2 H-STs without Fe, Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni0.5Fe1, Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni1Fe1, and Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni5Fe1, were synthesized by the same cyanogel hydrolysis strategy. EDX (Fig. S3) and SEM (Fig. S4) characterizations confirm their successful synthesis, indicating that via this preparation process, the chemical composition of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs can be conveniently adjusted in a controlled range by simply adjusting the feed ratio. The OER activities of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs were characterized by LSV (Fig. 4(A) ). The LSV curves show that among all samples, Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 has a lower onset potential and larger current density. The expected current density of solar water-splitting cells with the solar-to-fuel conversion efficiency of 10% is about 10 mA cm−2 under 1 sun illumination. Therefore, the overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 (η 10 = E 10 − 1.23 V) is a major parameter to evaluate the performance of a water-splitting device [ 51 ]. The η10 values of Ni(OH)2 H-STs, Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni5Fe1, Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1, Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni1Fe1, and Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni0.5Fe1 are 356, 255, 220, 276, and 336 mV, respectively (Fig. 4(B)). With the increasing iron content, the OER overpotential at Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 reaches a minimum value. Upon further increasing the iron content, the OER overpotential at Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni1Fe1 increases. Electrochemical measurements reveal that the Fe content plays an important role in the OER performance of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs. The introduction of iron can not only improve the conductivity of Ni(OH)2 H-STs [ 32,52–54 ] but can also change the electronic structure of Ni(OH)2 H-STs (Fig. S2). The LSV curves (Fig. 4(A)) show that the nickel oxidation peaks of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs undergo a positive shift with the increasing iron content and the higher valence NiIV active species are formed [ 55 ]. However, upon further increasing the iron content, the active sites of nickel on Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs are blocked by the inactive γ-FeOOH species [ 56 ], which decreases the activity of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs for the OER. To gain information about the OER kinetics of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs, Tafel plots (logj vs. η) were recorded (Fig. 4(C)). Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 shows a minimum Tafel slope (53 mV dec−1), which overmatches those of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni0.5Fe1 (87 mV dec−1), Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni1Fe1 (73 mV dec−1), Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni5Fe1 (75 mV dec−1), and Ni(OH)2 H-STs (76 mV dec−1). A Tafel slope between 40 and 120 mV dec−1 illustrates that the rate-determining steps on Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 are dominated by the Krasil'shcikov path involving the adsorption of OH− and the production of *-O− intermediate [ 57 ]. As Tafel slope serves as an estimable index of electron transfer rate for the OER, the present experimental results indicate that the OER at Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 has fastest reaction kinetics. The OER charge transfer rate at Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs was further explored by EIS (Fig. 4(D)). The EIS curves of all samples show a semicircular shape in the high frequency range, and the radius reflects the charge transfer resistance (Rs). Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 shows a smaller Rs value (6 Ω) than those of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni0.5Fe1 (68 Ω), Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni1Fe1 (35 Ω), Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni5Fe1(17 Ω), and Ni(OH)2 H-STs (390 Ω); this confirms the fast OER kinetics at Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1. 3.3 The OER performance of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1/NF As Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 has a high OER activity, we applied the same cyanogel hydrolysis strategy to directly grow Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 on NF. Compared to the smooth surface of NF (Fig. 5(A) ), the surface of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1/NF is rough (Fig. 5(B)); this provides an initial evidence about the successful combination of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 and NF. EDX-mapping images show the uniform distribution of Ni, Fe, and O elements, further proving the successful growth of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 on NF (Fig. 5(C)). The magnified SEM images show that Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 maintains its sheet morphology even after its growth on NF, very similar to the case of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 without NF (Fig. 5(D)). Generally, the in-situ growth of electrocatalysts on a conductive substrate can make them bond without the use of a binder; this accelerates the mass/electron transfer during electrocatalysis [ 58 ]. As NF has excellent conductivity, the direct growth of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 on NF undoubtedly facilitates mass/electron transfer. Meanwhile, open microporous 3D structures can accelerate the mass transfer of reactants and products. Thus, Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1/NF is expected to possess an enhanced OER activity as compared to that of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1 without NF. To investigate the possibility of practical applications of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1/NF, we compared its OER performance with that of commercial RuO2 nanoparticles on NF (denoted as RuO2/NF) under the same conditions. LSV measurements clearly show that Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1/NF has better activity, such as a lower onset oxidation potential and higher oxidation current, than commercial RuO2/NF for the OER (Fig. 6(A) ). At 10 and 60 mA cm−2, the η 10 and η 60 values of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1/NF are 200 mV and 250 mV, respectively, significantly lower than those of RuO2/NF (η 10 = 280 mV and η 60 = 340 mV) (Fig. 6(B)). In particular, the η 10 value of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1/NF is lower than that of most of the reported NiFe-based electrocatalysts (Table 1 ), also indicating its high activity. A comparative experiment was performed to exclude the contribution of NF (Fig. S5). Tafel plots show that the OER at Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1/NF has a smaller Tafel slope than that at RuO2/NF (56 vs. 111 mV dec−1, respectively), revealing improved OER kinetics at Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1/NF (Fig. 6(C)). The durability of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1/NF and RuO2/NF was investigated by chronopotentiometry measurements (Fig. 6(D)). After 15 h, the potential of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1/NF only increases by 30 mV, and its voltage at 10 mA cm−2 is still less than that of RuO2/NF, further indicating good durability and high activity of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1/NF. After stability test, the EDX and SEM characterizations show that the composition and morphology of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1/NF are basically maintained (Fig. S6). Possibly, the lamellar nanostructures can inhibit Ostwald ripening and support each other in three dimensions to prevent aggregation, which greatly improve the stability. 4 Conclusions Herein, we developed a simple mixed-cyanogel hydrolysis strategy to successfully synthesize Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs. The lamellate skeletons and the solid property of cyanogel precursor contributed to the formation of a holey and ultrathin 2D structure of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs. All electrochemical results demonstrate that Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1/NF with the optimal Ni/Fe ratio of 3:1 has excellent OER activity in an alkaline environment, which also exceeds that of most of the reported NiFe-based OER electrocatalysts. Due to the ultrathin 2D structure of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1, most of the metal atoms are exposed to the surface of sheets; this maximizes the atomic utilization. Simultaneously, the ultra-thin surface is filled with low-coordination-number central atoms with high activity, which can serve as highly active reaction sites for the OER. The pores on the sheets efficiently increase the amount of edge-active atoms with high activity and accelerate mass transfer. Meanwhile, the introduction of iron improves the conductivity of Ni(OH)2 H-STs and promotes the generation of valence NiIV active species. The introduction of NF with 3D morphology further improves the conductivity and accelerates mass transfer. All these factors contribute to the high OER activity of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs-Ni3Fe1/NF. coredata.dc:description: The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a half-reaction of water electrolysis, and the OER performance of an electrocatalyst is significantly related to its energy conversion efficiency. Due to their high OER activity, transition metal-based nanomaterials have become potential low-cost substitutes for Ir/Ru-based OER electrocatalysts in an alkaline environment. Herein, holey Fe3O4-coupled Ni(OH)2 sheets (Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs) were easily achieved by a simple mixed-cyanogel hydrolysis strategy. The two-dimensional (2D) Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs with ca. 1 nm thickness have a high specific surface area, abundant unsaturated coordination atoms, and numerous pores, which are highly favorable for electrocatalytic reactions. Meanwhile, the introduction of Fe improves the conductivity and regulates the electronic structure of Ni. Due to their special structural features and synergistic effect between the Fe and Ni atoms, Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs with an optimal Ni/Fe ratio show excellent OER activity in a 1 M KOH solution, which significantly exceeds that of the commercial RuO2 nanoparticle electrocatalyst. Furthermore, Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs can be grown on nickel foam (NF), and the resulting material exhibits enhanced OER activity, such as a small overpotential of 200 mV and a small Tafel slope of 56 mV dec−1, than that of Ni(OH)2-Fe H-STs without NF.

coredata.dc:title: Direct growth of holey Fe3O4-coupled Ni(OH)2 sheets on nickel foam for the oxygen evolution reaction
